item.title: Why can't the government stop the financial sector from paying out record bonuses this year, when the banks' actions triggered a recession?
item.description:
+6
Votes

According to the New York Times, Wall Street bonuses this year are set to be one of "largest and most controversial blowouts the industry has ever seen."

Yet most expert accounts of crisis--which pitched the world economy into a recession and caused tremendous hardship among ordinary people--place significant blame on a culture of short-term profit, and perverse incentives, that led the financial sector to inflate a bubble of epic proportions. Moreover, wages among average Americans have mostly stagnated over the past years, while the financial sector has driven GDP growth, growth that has been seemingly illusory.

So why is that the US political system can't, unlike Britain, introduce limits on executive compensation, or try to force that executive compensation to be spread over the long-term? Is it really because, as bankers say, our economic interests lie in rewarding bankers for their productive contributions to society? Or is it a straightforward case of powerful interests taking care of themselves?

item.title: Why is the Daily Mail such a hate-filled paranoid rag?
item.description:
-5
Votes

Time after time, the Daily Mail splashes with headlines about x,y or z causing cancer, or such and such a minority group conniving to defraud the tax-payers of their hard earned money. Often the headline is either misleading or just plain wrong. Why do they continue like this, and how do ordinary journalists, rather than the high profile loud-mouths writing the opinion columns, feel about working for such a scandalous rag?

item.title: Why didn't anyone else pick up Plain Dealer's Nov. scoop that photog destroyed most incriminating My Lai shots? http://tinyurl.com/y95yahr
item.description:
0
Votes

My link above explains the basics and links to the original content. I'm interested in this because I think it either says something about the flow of information from Cleveland to the rest of the world or something about our short-sighted sense of newsworthiness that this story went essentially nowhere. I say "essentially nowhere." That's not quite right. After I blogged about this, the BBC got in touch and interviewed me about it. But there seems to have been little, if any, interest here in the U.S. I'm grateful for that in one sense. There could have been a feeding frenzy, a massive public shaming of someone who -- whatever evidence he may have destroyed -- is the reason why we have any photos at all of the My Lai massacre. Fundamentally, it's just an interesting story about war, about ethics, about the decades-long fallout of tragedies and outrages.

0

item.title: Is there a tablet that is does not require phone service contract? Use like iPod to stream/download Google Reader, iTunes Videos, Hulu etc.
item.description:
0
Votes

I read a lot of blogs and watch videos referenced in news. It would be great to be able to do this from a network device in my house. This device would access my home wireless network to browse the Internet, read email and etc. It would not require a full keyboard if you could flag items to act upon later from your pc. My thinking is that this would be a cheaper device than a table with a keyboard. It would also be cheaper because you would not have to sign up for a cell phone service contract. Another good feature would be the ability to download preselected services for off line viewing.
